Q10_9_TEXT: I have translated two novels with a colleague and I have coordinated a number of translation projects involving the participation of last-year undergraduate students. These translations were published.
Q13_9_TEXT: I have never seriously thought about the possibility of using MT in the translation of literature. It is not a matter of liking or disliking.

Q13: I like using MT to check certain words or expressions.,I don't like using MT because it makes me less creative.,I don't like using MT because of ethical issues (machines replacing translators, companies getting my data, etc.),I like using MT to trigger my creativity.,I don't like using MT because the proposals are very poor.,I don't like working with MT because I cannot trust it.,Other
Q13_9_TEXT: In business translation I like using MT to check words/ expressions. In literary translation my experience is that MT (Dutch) fails to recognise tone & register, also that using MT creates inconsistencies in tone & register which are unwelcome: as a reader of a literary text, you would like to be 'the voice' of a story to be one and the same - you would like to have one and the same interlocutor, as it were.
